conclusion: Setup involves a charged particle launched horizontally with velocity v₀ through a uniform downward electric field E, entering a magnetic field at point P with a 60° angle between its velocity and PQ.
The particle experiences a downward force F = qE in the electric field, causing downward acceleration a = qE/m.
The particle's initial velocity is horizontal (v₀), and its motion follows a parabolic path similar to projectile motion.
The time taken to reach point P is t = x/v₀, where x is the horizontal distance from the launch point to P.
The vertical displacement after time t is y = qEx²/(2mv₀²).
The vertical velocity component at time t is v_y = qEx/(mv₀).
At point P, the particle's velocity components are horizontal: v₀ and vertical: v_y = qEx/(mv₀).
The magnitude of the velocity at P is v_P = √(v₀² + (qEx/(mv₀))²).
The angle between the velocity vector at P and the vertical line PQ is 60°, meaning the angle with the horizontal is 30°.
Using tan(30°) = 1/√3, we find tan(30°) = v_y/v₀ = qEx/(mv₀²).
Solving for x gives x = mv₀²/(qE√3).
The distance from the particle's launch position to point P is x = mv₀²/(qE√3).
